column1: Camden Town ( (listen))
column2: often shortened to Camden (also the name for the borough it is in)
column3: is a district of northwest London
column5: 2.5 miles (4.1 km) north of Charing Cross. Historically in Middlesex
column6: it is the administrative centre of the London Borough of Camden
column7: and identified in the London Plan as one of 34 major centres in Greater London.

column1: Laid out as a residential district from 1791 and originally part of the manor of Kentish Town and the parish of St Pancras
column2: Camden Town became an important location during the early development of the railways
column3: which reinforced its position on the London canal network. The area's industrial economic base has been replaced by service industries such as retail
column4: tourism and entertainment. The area now hosts street markets and music venues that are strongly associated with alternative culture.

column1: == History ==
=== Toponymy ===
Camden Town is named after Charles Pratt
column2: 1st Earl Camden. His earldom was styled after his estate
column3: Camden Place near Chislehurst in Kent (now in the London Borough of Bromley)
column4: formerly owned by historian William Camden. The name
column5: which appears on the Ordnance Survey map of 1822
column6: was later applied to the early-20th-century Camden Town Group of artists and the London Borough of Camden

column1: === Urban development ===
Camden Town stands on land that was once the manor of Kentish Town. Sir Charles Pratt
column2: a radical 18th-century lawyer and politician
column3: acquired the manor through marriage. In 1791
column4: he started granting leases for houses to be built in the manor. In 1816
column5: the Regent's Canal was built through the area. Up to at least the mid-20th century
column6: Camden Town was considered an "unfashionable" locality. The Camden markets
column7: which started in 1973 and have grown since then
column8: attract many visitors. A 1993 bomb blast injured 18 people on Camden High Street. On 9 February 2008
column9: Camden Canal market suffered a major fire
column10: but there were no injuries. It later reopened as Camden Lock Village

column1: == Governance ==
Camden Town
column2: previously in the Metropolitan Borough of St Pancras
column3: became part of the London Borough of Camden when it was created in 1965.

column1: === Political constituencies ===
Camden Town is contained in the following political constituencies for different purposes
column2: listed with some incumbents as of 22 May 2019:

column1: Camden London Borough Council: London Borough of Camden. 54 councillors
column2: Labour control.

column1: Camden Town with Primrose Hill (ward)
column2: returns three Borough councillors (all Labour).

column1: UK Parliament: Holborn and St Pancras. Keir Starmer
column2: Labour Party.

column1: London Assembly: Barnet and Camden. Andrew Dismore
column2: Labour Party.

column1: === Council wards ===
The area is largely covered by the Camden Town with Primrose Hill ward. As of 2020
column2: Camden's wards are being reviewed and this ward will be abolished or have its boundary redrawn.

column1: == Geography ==
Camden Town is on relatively flat ground at 100 feet (30 m) above sea level
column2: 2.5 miles (4.0 km) north-northwest of Charing Cross. To the north are the hills of Hampstead and Highgate. The culverted
column3: subterranean River Fleet flows from its source on Hampstead Heath through Camden Town south to the Thames. The Regent's Canal runs through the north of Camden Town.

column1: == Economy ==
At the end of the 20th century
column2: entertainment-related businesses began moving into the area
column3: and a Holiday Inn was built abutting the canal. A number of retail and food chain outlets replaced independent shops
column4: driven out by high rents and redevelopment. Restaurants with a variety of culinary traditions thrived
column5: many of them near the markets
column6: on Camden High Street and its side streets
column9: and Bayham Street. The plan to redevelop the historic Stables Market led to a steel and glass extension
column10: built on the edges of the site in 2006

column1: === Camden street markets ===
Camden is well known for its markets. These date from 1974 or later
column2: except for Inverness Street market
column3: for over a century a small food market serving the local community
column4: though by 2013 all foodstuff and produce stalls had gone and only touristy stalls remained. Camden Lock market proper started in a former timber yard in 1973
column5: and is now surrounded by five more markets: Buck Street market
column8: and an indoor market in the Electric Ballroom. The markets are a major tourist attraction at weekends
column14: junk/antiques and more bizarre items; they and the surrounding shops are popular with young people
column16: those searching for "alternative" clothing. While originally open on Sundays only
column17: market activity later extended throughout the week

column1: == Transport ==
=== London Underground ===
Camden Town Tube station is near the markets and other attractions. It is a key interchange station for the Bank and Charing Cross branches of the southbound Northern Line
column2: and the Edgware and High Barnet branches of the northbound Northern Line. The station was not designed to cope with the volume of traffic it handles since the area increased in popularity. It is very crowded at weekends
column3: and
column5: is closed to outbound passengers on Sunday afternoons for safety reasons.London Underground has made many proposals to upgrade the station. In 2004 a proposal requiring the compulsory purchase and demolition of 'the Triangle'—land bordered by Kentish Town Road
column6: Buck Street and Camden High Street—was rejected by Camden Council after opposition from local people; of 229 letters
column7: only two supported the scheme. Chalk Farm and Mornington Crescent tube stations also serve the area. It was later planned to redevelop the station entirely between 2020 and 2024/5
column8: with less demolition than proposed previously
column9: but the redevelopment  was postponed in December 2018 by TfL "until we have the funds we need".Camden Town tube station is exit-only at times when market-related traffic would cause dangerous overcrowding on the narrow platforms; as of 2018 on Sundays from 13:00 to 17:30. At these times
column10: alternative stations within walking distance are Mornington Crescent

column1: === Rail ===

Camden Road is a London Overground station at the corner of Royal College Street and Camden Road. It is on the line from Richmond in the West to Stratford station in the East. The nearest National Rail station is Kentish Town on the Thameslink route on the Midland Main Line. St Pancras and Euston terminals are both within 20 minutes' walk of Camden Town.
=== Roads ===
The area is a major hub for London Buses. Parts of the A503 (Camden Road) and A400 (Camden High Street and Camden Street) are designated as red routes on which vehicles may not stop for any reason
column2: managed by Transport for London rather than the borough. Black taxis ply for hire in the area and there are minicab offices.

column1: === Cycling ===
Transport for London and Camden Council both provide and maintain cycling infrastructure in Camden Town. Segregated cycle tracks run alongside Royal College Street to the east of Camden Town
column2: past Camden Road railway station. Royal College Street is also part of Quietway 1
column3: which links Camden Town to the rest of London's cycle network at King's Cross
column4: Covent Garden and Kentish Town.The Regent's Canal towpath is a shared-use path maintained by the Canal and River Trust. The towpath links Camden Town to Angel and King's Cross to the east
column5: and Regent's Park and Maida Vale in the west.The London-wide Santander Cycles cycle hire scheme operates in Camden Town. There are several docking stations
column6: including at Camden Road railway station (Bonny Street) and Camden Town tube station (Greenland Road).Cycle counters on Royal College Street to the north of Camden Road railway station recorded over 375

column1: === Regent's Canal ===
Regent's Canal runs through the north end of Camden Town. Canal boat trips along the canal from Camden Lock are popular
column2: particularly in summer. Many of the handrails by the bridges show deep marks worn by the towropes by which horses pulled canal barges until the 1950s
column3: and it is still possible to see ramps on the canal bank designed to assist horses that fell in the canal after being startled by the noise of a train. Camden Lock is a regularly used traditional manually operated double canal lock operating between widely separated levels. A large complex of weekend street markets operates around the Lock. The towpath is a pedestrian and cycle route which runs continuously from Little Venice through Camden Lock to the Islington Tunnel. A regular waterbus service operates along the Regent's Canal from Camden Lock. Boats depart every hour during the summer
column5: calling at London Zoo and on towards Maida Vale. Sightseeing narrow-boat trips run from Camden Lock to Little Venice.

column1: == Notable places ==
The Roundhouse is a former locomotive engine roundhouse constructed in 1847 for the London & North Western Railway. It later had various uses
column2: including a corn and potato store
column3: Gilbey's gin warehouse
column4: and eventually became derelict until it was converted to a theatre
column5: arts centre and music venue in 1966
column7: and reopened in 2006 as a theatre and music venue.

column1: Camden catacombs (see also Catacombs of London)
column2: not true catacombs but an underground area largely underneath the Camden markets
column3: originally used as stables for horses and pit ponies used to shunt railway wagons. Not open to visitors due to danger of flooding.

column1: St Pancras Old Church
Our Lady of Hal
column2: Catholic church for the area

column1: The Camden Eye at 2 Kentish Town Road
column2: was formerly known and as the Old Mother Red Cap
column3: the Red Cap and Halfway House. It was also used as a prison.

column1: St Michael's Church
column2: Camden Town

column1: Greater London House
column2: formerly the Carreras Cigarette Factory and now housing several companies
column3: a striking Art Deco Egyptian Revival building dating from 1926 to 1928
column4: stands at Mornington Crescent and is distinguished by a pair of 8.5-foot (2.6 m)-high bronze statues of the Egyptian cat goddess Bastet.

column1: Jewish Museum
Arlington House
column2: originally one of the Rowton Houses providing low-cost overnight accommodation
column3: now housing a conference centre but still providing low-cost rooms and flats.

column1: The unusual Sainsbury's supermarket and flats on Camden Road were designed in a high-tech style by Nicholas Grimshaw and built on the site of the former large ABC Bakery.

The Hawley Arms is a pub and music venue which became well known in the 90s as a hub for the indie and alternative music scene in London. It was Amy Winehouse's favourite pub when she lived in Camden Town
column2: and she was rumoured to get behind the bar to pull pints and serve drinks.

== Notable people ==
Ambush (rapper)
B. R. Ambedkar (social reformer
column2: jurist and LSE graduate) lived at 10
column3: King Henry Road

column1: Richard Ryan lived in Camden Town from 1819 until his death in 1849.
Charles Dickens's second London home was in Bayham Street in 1822. He later moved to 112 Little College Street (now College Place)
column2: where he boarded with Elizabeth Roylance
column3: a family friend
column4: whom Dickens later immortalised as "Mrs. Pipchin" in Dombey and Son.

column1: Beryl Bainbridge lived in Albert Street from the 1960s until her death in 2010.
Playwright Alan Bennett lived in Gloucester Crescent for many years. Margaret Fairchild (aka Miss Shepherd) lived in a van on his driveway
Physicist
column2: mathematician
column3: and engineer Oliver Heaviside was born in Camden Town.

column1: The author and journalist Bernard Levin grew up in Camden Town's Plender Street.
The boxer Tom Sayers lived in Camden
column2: and died at No. 257 Camden High Street in 1865. The house now has a plaque.

column1: The painter Walter Sickert lived and worked as part of the Camden Town Group in Mornington Crescent. In 1908 he painted a group of four paintings collectively titled The Camden Town Murder
column2: in reference to the notorious Camden Town Murder case of 1907.

column1: Poet Dylan Thomas owned a house at 54 Delancey Street from 1951 until his death in 1953. There is a plaque on the house today.
Singer Amy Winehouse lived in Camden Town
column2: first on Prowse Place and then on Camden Square
column3: where she was found dead in July 2011. Winehouse was strongly associated with Camden Town. Since her death she has been entitled as "The Queen of Camden" and a bronze statue of her was placed in Stables Market on what would have been her 31st birthday

column1: Hip-hop trio N-Dubz are from and grew up in the area.
Music Band Madness are from and grew up in Camden Town and surrounding areas.
Singer Eliza Doolittle grew up in the area.
Jazz Musician Nubya Garcia was born and grew up Camden Town.
Actor Freddie Highmore was born in Camden Town in 1992.
The dancer and actress Donna King teaches at her studio in Camden Town.
The journalist and novelist Sean Thomas lives in Camden.Songwriter and singer Dua Lipa grew up in Camden until she moved to Kosovo
== Media ==
=== National ===
To the north of Camden Town station and running along the canal is a modern pop art complex designed by Terry Farrell as the studios of the former TV-am
column2: now used by MTV but retaining TV-am's eggcup sculptures along the roof line. Associated Press Television News has its head office in a former gin warehouse near Camden Lock called "The Interchange".

column1: === Local ===
The Camden New Journal is a free
column2: independent weekly newspaper that covers the London Borough of Camden.

column1: Camden TV
== In popular culture ==
=== In literature ===
Author Charles Dickens
column2: a onetime resident of Camden Town
column3: placed various characters and places in his stories there as well: Bob Cratchit's family in A Christmas Carol (1843); the Micawbers in David Copperfield (1850); and in Dombey and Son (1846–1848)
column4: a description of the building of the London and Birmingham Railway
column5: includes a trip through Camden Town.

column1: E. Nesbit's 1904 children's novel The Phoenix and the Carpet is set at 18 Camden Terrace
column2: Camden Town.

column1: John Betjeman's poem "Business Girls" is set in Camden Town.
The climax of John le Carré's 1974 spy novel Tinker
column2: Tailor
column3: Soldier
column4: Spy occurs in a safe house at 5 Lock Gardens in Camden Town
column5: a fictitious address modelled after real-life St. Mark's Crescent.

column1: === In film and television ===
The 1986 cult comedy film Withnail and I is set in Camden Town in 1969.
The 1989 comedy film The Tall Guy stars Jeff Goldblum as the titular protagonist
column2: who we frequently see bicycling to his flat set in Camden Town.

column1: The 2008 Mike Leigh film Happy-Go-Lucky largely takes place in Camden Town.
The 2015 film The Lady in the Van tells the story of a homeless woman who parked her van in Alan Bennett's Camden driveway and lived there for 15 years.
The 2015 film Amy
column2: the documentary based on Amy Winehouse's life and death features footage and exclusive images of Winehouse in Camden during her life.

column1: The 2018 film Been So Long is set in Camden Town.
The 2019 Disney animated series 101 Dalmatian Street is set in Camden Town.
In Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019)
column2: a mission named "Clean House" is set in Camden Town.
